It isn't exactly a conspiracy theory to state that Riot will.. maybe rig is too strong of a word, but *control* matchmaking in such a way as to prioritize many different things over game quality - likely engagement.

A priority towards game quality would, off the top of my head:

* **Absolutely never** give players matches outside of a sane MMR bracket.. challengers in plat games, diamonds in silver games - that last one happened to me [and I have the screenshot to prove it](https://i.imgur.com/Hi30qL0.png).
* Visibly handle odd game conditions with an aim to recognizing the skill disparities those conditions cause (autofilled players in impactful roles, modified MMR/rank calculation on players leaving - your rank should reflect *reality* at the end of the day)
* Allow people to see their own current skill level *as matched* by the system
* Make it a priority to remove smurfs, trolls, and chronic disconnectors from the ladder in a way that otherwise honest players don't have to put up with their demonstrably negative impact on their ratings.
* Nuke the concept of "promotion/demotion" games from orbit and salt the earth

There are many things Riot could be doing to make matchmaking better for every player. Those things aren't being done. In fact, as best as I can tell, there are no meaningful changes to matchmaking being made, period. The last thing we were told about is the positional matchmaking from last seasons.

That leads naturally into the question of "Why?" and the easy answer is "engagement == money". That goes double when they go out of their way to hide that information ***and take the extra step of preventing anyone else from trying to estimate that information*** (see API terms of service).

If everything is above board, why hide?

> We got folks with 1,000 + games going on they are better then their ranks. I climbed thru the same bracket that season in exactly 50 matches. Playing supports. Because people insisted it was impossible and I don't know what the "Lower" Elo experience was like. Disagreed. Proved what I said by fucking doing it.

If you have 1000 games in a season, we're beyond the point of the things I'm complaining about. That's 500ish hours of League and more than enough time for the matchmaker to stop jerking you around and have your MMR and your rank close to each other. My gripe is about the system's ~~inability~~ programmed unwillingness  to do this for more casual players who can't put in literal months worth of game time in every single season.

> But much more then that, I don't want them on my team or in my games giving up and wasting my time because boo fucking hoo 1 lane lost better soft int and whine about Rito keeping them down. It. Player behavior and choices impact gameplay.

While we're passing blame around, how much does a game design that disincentivizes good sportsmanship and incentivizes quick surrenders get? While it might feel good to shit on people for easy surrendering, by the numbers, it's better for your rank to get out of games that are wildly uneven quickly and get into another one than it is to spend the extra time trying for an unlikely comeback.
 
> I don't like the hypocrisy. DONT TALK ABOUT RIOTS SYSTEM YOU KNOW NOTHING ON WHAT THEY DO!  From some one who is making thread after thread after thread after thread on the topic. What a shitty double standard.

This tells us nothing useful without some more info behind it. We already know they're doing some weighting/per-position tracking after last year - how is that calculated? Do they just average the team MMR and calculate the expected results that way? Is it position vs position? What happens when someone disconnects? What happens when you win lane but lose game? What are the upper and lower rating bounds? What is the expected ratings range for each rank? What's the K-factor? How do we know it's Elo and not something more advanced like Glicko2?

Just saying "its Elo" can't even be substantiated after season 2, and even if we knew it for a fact, there are so many unknowns that it's basically worthless for giving you information to act on.

The three things about MMR Riot doesn't explain and isn't basic:

How it calculates LP/MMR gains based on its win rates and consecutive performance.

What its baseline positional ranking average is weighted at.

What rank it is weighted to be the median MMR.

---------------

Prior to Season 9, the baseline was 1550 MMR, which was Gold IV. After Season 9's Positional ranking, Riot claimed they were keeping position ranking in the calculations for MMR, but didn't go beyond that in its explanation.

What rankings/stats are making it appear like:

-Baseline is being dragged down to Silver III, weighting LP gains around a Silver III expectation MMR (if you are much lower, your LP gains will be high, but if you are near Silver III or higher, the LP gains are shorter than the Gold IV expectation)

This creates a rubber band effect at the extremes, trying to pull both ends back towards Silver III, especially at the skewed higher ends (diamond+)

It's almost impossible to get pitted in Iron IV-II, because the LP gains are so large, that even trolling and getting 40% win rate will drag you out of it. Conversely, since Diamond is trying to pull you back instead of forward, LP gains are dismally lower.

- LP gain and loss is based on the difference between one's rank and rank equivalent of the average MMR of the enemy team. MMR gain and loss is based on the difference between one's MMR and the average MMR of the enemy team.
- What does that mean?
- I'd like to know as well, but does it matter beyond just having the knowledge (which I agree is important)?

There is no rubberbanding. Being above the middle doesn't lessen one's gains and increase one's losses and being below the middle doesn't increase one's gains and lessen one's losses. What does exist is MMR will move more slowly than LP. That's why if one goes on a win streak, one's LP gains will decrease and losses will increase while if one goes on a loss streak, one's LP gains will increase and losses will decrease. Unless one maintains the streak, the rank and MMR equivalents will approach each other and the gains and losses will approach the baseline. 

One could argue that Riot does it to simultaneously slow down progress and help ensure people don't fall too low too quickly because doing so might discourage them. I think it's partially that but mostly to lessen the impact of streaks. I'm sure there are other reasonable theories.
